ingredients: 1. Rinse the okra and trim off the stems. Cut the okra into 1-inch pieces and set aside.
2. In a large pot, heat the coconut oil over medium-high heat. Add the onion and garlic and sautÃ© until translucent, about 2-3 minutes.
3. Add the diced red bell pepper to the pot and cook for another 2-3 minutes.
4. Stir in the red curry paste, ground coriander, ground cumin, turmeric, and salt. Cook for 1-2 minutes, until fragrant.
5. Pour in the vegetable soup and bring it to a simmer.
6. Add the okra to the pot and let it cook for about 8-10 minutes, until it is tender.
7. Pour in the coconut milk and stir in the soy sauce. Let the curry simmer for another 5 minutes.
8. Taste the curry and adjust the seasoning if needed. Add more salt, soy sauce according to your taste.

ingredients: 2. In a large pot, add the soup and bring it to a boil. Reduce the heat and let it simmer while you prepare the other ingredients.

4. Heat up the palm oil on medium-high heat. Add the blended mixture and let it cook for about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
5. Add the egusi to the pot and stir until well combined. Allow it to cook for 5 more minutes.
6. Now, add the prepared okra and stir gently. Let it cook for another 5 minutes.

ingredients: 1. Soak the dried chickpeas in water overnight or for at least 8 hours. Drain and rinse before using.
2. In a large pot, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add the diced onion and minced garlic, and cook until softened, about 5 minutes.
3. Add the soaked chickpeas to the pot along with the cumin, paprika, coriander, ginger, turmeric, cinnamon, and cayenne pepper. Stir to coat the chickpeas in the spices and cook for 2-3 minutes.
4. Pour in the diced tomatoes, vegetable broth, and water. Stir to combine and bring to a simmer. Cover the pot and let it cook for 1 hour, or until the chickpeas are tender.

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: _In a large bowl, crack and whisk 2 eggs. Tear the tofu into small chunks using your hands and add them to the bowl. If your tofu still has a lot of liquid, squeeze it over the sink to get rid of the excess. Mix well with the eggs._
*Add into the bowl 1.5 teaspoons of curry powder, 1/2 teaspoon of garlic powder, 1/4 teaspoon of salt, and 1/4 cup of panko crumbs. Mix thoroughly to evenly coat the tofu. Set aside.*
*_Heat a large non-stick frying pan with 1-2 tablespoons of cooking oil._*

*Once the oil is hot, add the 1/4 cup of cornflour onto the tofu pieces and mix to coat them evenly. Immediately transfer the tofu chunks into the pan and fry for 8 minutes over medium heat. You may need to use a spatula to separate the chunks as it's a very batter-heavy recipe.*

_Once cooked, if there's some remaining oil in the pan, transfer the chunks into a bowl. Toss them with 1/2 tablespoon of vegetable stock powder. If the pan doesn't have much oil left, mix the vegetable stock powder in the pan to season the tofu evenly._
*These tofu chunks make a great standalone snack or you can even roll them into a wrap for a satisfying lunch.*

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen

ingredients: 1. Begin by preparing the vegetables. Cut the zucchinis into thick slices, deseed and slice the bell peppers, and slice the red onion. Peel and mince the garlic cloves.
2. Preheat your grill to medium-high heat. Meanwhile, drain the block of tofu and pat it dry with paper towels. Cut the tofu into bite-sized cubes.
3. In a small bowl, mix together the soy sauce, honey, ginger powder, and a pinch of salt.
4. In a large bowl, add the sliced vegetables and tofu. Pour the marinade over the vegetables and tofu, and gently toss to ensure everything is coated evenly.

5. Thread the vegetables and tofu onto skewers, alternating between them. If using wooden skewers, make sure to soak them in water for at least 30 minutes beforehand to prevent them from burning on the grill.
6. Grill the skewers for 10-12 minutes, turning occasionally, until the vegetables are slightly charred and the tofu is heated through.
7. While the skewers are grilling, heat a large wok or pan over medium-high heat. Add 2 tablespoons of olive oil and swirl to coat the pan.
8. Cut the sanguage sausages into bite-sized pieces and add them to the pan. Stir-fry for 3-4 minutes until slightly browned.
9. Add the minced garlic to the pan and stir-fry for an additional minute.

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: 10. Add the cooked rice to the pan and stir-fry for 2-3 minutes until heated through.
11. Once the skewers are done, remove them from the grill and slide the vegetables and tofu off the skewers into the stir-fry pan. Stir-fry for another 2-3 minutes until everything is well.

*_Savory Spinach and Feta Crepes using Whole Wheat Flour_*

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: 1. In a large mixing bowl, combine the whole wheat flour, eggs, milk, melted butter and a pinch of salt. Whisk until well combined and smooth. Let the batter rest for 10 minutes.
2. In a non-stick pan, heat a small amount of olive oil over medium heat.
3. Wash the spinach thoroughly and remove any tough stems. Chop the spinach into small pieces.
4. Once the pan is hot, pour a ladle full of the crepe batter and swirl it around to cover the bottom of the pan. Cook for about 1-2 minutes until the edges start to brown.
5. Sprinkle a handful of chopped spinach on one half of the crepe and crumble some feta cheese on top.
6. Using a spatula, fold the other half of the crepe over the spinach and feta filling, creating a half-moon shape. Press down lightly with the spatula to seal the edges.
7. Cook for another 1-2 minutes until the bottom is golden brown.
8. Carefully flip the crepe over and cook for another minute until the other side is also golden brown.
9. Repeat the process with the remaining batter and filling, adding more oil to the pan as needed.
10. Serve the savory spinach and feta crepes hot.
*_Chocolate Chip Banana Bread made with Wheat Flour_*

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: 1. Preheat your oven to 350ÂºF (175ÂºC) and grease a 9x5 inch loaf pan.
2. In a large mixing bowl, combine the wheat flour, baking soda, baking powder, and salt. Set aside.
3. In a separate bowl, mash the ripe bananas until smooth.
4. Add in the melted butter, brown sugar, vanilla extract, and eggs to the mashed bananas and mix until well combined.
5. Slowly pour the wet banana mixture into the dry flour mixture and stir until just combined.
6. Gently fold in the chocolate chips.
7. Pour the batter into the greased loaf pan and smooth the top with a spatula.
8. Bake for 50-60 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean.
9. Let the bread cool in the pan for 10 minutes, then remove and transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.
- Make sure to use ripe bananas for maximum sweetness and flavor in the bread.
- You can substitute whole wheat flour for regular wheat flour for a healthier option.
- For an extra burst of flavor, you can add 1 tsp of cinnamon to the dry flour mixture.
- Store any leftovers in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 3 days, or in the refrigerator for up to a week. You can also freeze slices for longer storage.

ingredients: 1. In a small pan, toast the cumin and coriander seeds over medium heat until fragrant, about 2-3 minutes. Remove from heat and crush the seeds using a mortar and pestle or a spice grinder.
2. In a mixing bowl, combine the crushed seeds with minced garlic, olive oil, honey, and apple cider vinegar. Whisk until well combined.
3. Add the beetroot and carrot strips to the dressing and toss to coat evenly. Let it marinate for at least 30 minutes, or up to 2 hours, in the refrigerator.

6. Serve as a side dish or as a light lunch.

Black Bean and Quinoa Burgers with Avocado and Tomato Salsa

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: - 1 can black beans, drained and rinsed

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: 1. In a large mixing bowl, mash the black beans with a fork or potato masher.
2. Add in the cooked quinoa, finely diced red onion, minced garlic, cumin, smoked paprika, chili powder, salt, black pepper, breadcrumbs, and egg. Mix until well combined.
3. Divide the mixture into 4 equal portions and shape into burger patties.
4. Heat a large skillet over medium heat and add a drizzle of olive oil. Once hot, add the burger patties and cook for 4-5 minutes on each side or until golden brown and crispy.
5. While the burgers are cooking, prepare the avocado and tomato salsa. In a separate bowl, combine the diced avocado, tomato, chopped cilantro, lime juice, and salt and pepper to taste.
6. Once the burgers are cooked, assemble the burgers by placing a patty on a bun and topping with the avocado and tomato salsa.
7. Serve the as a delicious and wholesome vegetarian meal for Father's Day.

ingredients: 1. Heat the vegetable oil in a pan on medium-high heat.
2. Add the onions, ginger, green chili and sautÃ© until lightly browned.
3. Add the cubed paneer and mix.
4. Add the garam masala, cumin powder, turmeric powder, coriander leaves and salt to taste. Mix well.
5. Take the samosas and gently open each one up.
6. Stuff the samosas with the paneer mixture.
7. Heat another pan on medium-high heat and add some vegetable oil.
8. Fry the stuffed samosas until golden brown on both sides.
9. Serve hot with chutney of your choice.

*Paneer can be made with milk, goat milk, sheep milk or cow's milk. Although it is similar to cottage cheese, paneer is usually made without rennet and therefore has a different texture. Paneer is made by curdling milk with a food acid, usually lemon juice or vinegar.*

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: Bay leaves: A common ingredient in Italian soups and stews. It adds a subtle herbal note and enhances the overall flavor of the soup.
Sea salt to taste: Season generously towards the end.
Extra virgin olive oil: For sautÃ©ing the soffritto and for the serving.
Drizzle some high-quality olive oil over the finished soup before serving.
Rinse the lentils thoroughly. This helps remove any impurities and ensures a clean taste.
In a large pot, heat olive oil over medium heat.
Add the diced onion, carrot, and celery, and sautÃ© until they soften.
Add the rinsed lentils, bay leaf, chopped tomato, and broth to the pot.
Bring to a boil, then let it simmer in a lower heat for about 30-40 minutes, or until the lentils are tender.
Once the lentils are cooked, remove the bay leaf and season the soup with salt.
Ladle the hot soup into bowls and finish with a drizzle of olive oil and fresh basil or parsley.
Serve as a main course with crusty bread or your favorite side dish.ğŸ˜‹ğŸ˜‹ğŸ˜‹
TOP TIPS FOR A DELICIOUS SOUP
Rinse dried lentils well before cooking to remove any dust or debris.
Lentil soup thickens as it sits â€“ add more broth as needed when reheating.
Use vegetable stock to make a vegetarian lentil soup.
Veggie power: Add more vegetables to the mix.
Zucchini, swiss chard, bell peppers, baby spinach, or fresh kale can be excellent additions to boost the nutritional value.
Creamy soup: If you prefer a creamier texture, blend a portion of the cooked soup using an immersion or regular blender.
Pour it back into the pot and stir to combine.
Add Pasta: Itâ€™s something nice to do with leftovers the next day.
Cook the pasta directly in the lentils, adding about 2 cups of water. Serve with a sprinkle of parmesan cheese.
*If you have leftovers or want to make a big batch of Italian lentil soup ahead of time, hereâ€™s how you can store it:*
Fridge: Allow the soup to cool completely before transferring it to an airtight container.
It will stay fresh in the refrigerator for 4-5 days.
Freeze: If you want to extend the soupâ€™s shelf life, freezing is the way to go.
Portion the soup into freezer-safe containers or resealable freezer bags, leaving some room for expansion. It can be frozen for three months.
Thaw in the refrigerator overnight before reheating.
*DO YOU SOAK THE LENTILS BEFORE COOKING?*
No, you donâ€™t need to soak the lentils before cooking.
*_Unlike some other legumes, lentils cook relatively quickly without pre-soaking. Just give them a good rinse before putting them in the pot._*
CAN I USE CANNED LENTILS INSTEAD OF DRY?
While dried lentils are preferred for their texture and flavor, you can certainly use canned lentils if youâ€™re short on time or like the convenience.
Drain and rinse the canned lentils before adding them to the soup. Remember that canned lentils are already cooked, so youâ€™re the cooking time to avoid overcooking them.
CAN I USE OTHER TYPES OF LENTILS?
Yes! While the recipe calls for dried lentils, you can experiment with different types, such as green lentils, brown, or black.

ingredients: 1. In a medium saucepan, combine the groundnut butter, coconut milk, water, rolled oats, banana slices, honey, chia seeds, ground cinnamon, and vanilla extract. Stir well to combine.
2. Place the saucepan over medium heat and bring the mixture to a boil. Reduce heat to low and let the porridge simmer for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally.
3. While the porridge is simmering, preheat a small non-stick skillet over medium heat. Add the shredded coconut and toast for 2-3 minutes until golden brown. Set aside.
4. Once the porridge is cooked and thickened to your desired consistency, remove from heat and let it cool for a few minutes.
5. Transfer the porridge to a serving bowl and top with the toasted coconut.

_Enjoy your hot, or let it cool down and refrigerate for a yummy breakfast the next day. You can also add additional toppings such as fresh fruit, nuts, or a drizzle of extra honey for added sweetness._

*This creamy and delicious porridge bowl is a perfect blend of African and tropical flavors, making it a unique and flavorful breakfast option. The groundnut butter adds protein and healthy fats, while the coconut milk adds a rich and creamy texture. This recipe can be easily adjusted to your liking by adding more or less water depending on how thick you prefer your porridge. So next time you're craving a warm and comforting breakfast, give this a try!ğŸ˜‹ğŸ˜‹ğŸ˜‹*

4. Place the bowl or container in the refrigerator and let the oats soak overnight, or for at least 6-8 hours.
5. In the morning, give the oats a quick stir. If the mixture is too thick, you can add more coconut milk or water to achieve your desired consistency.
6. Transfer the oat mixture into serving bowls or jars. Top with sliced almonds, extra diced mango, and a drizzle of honey (or maple syrup) for sweetness.
Enjoy your delicious and nutritious for a quick and easy breakfast or snack option.
- You can use any type of vegan yogurt for this recipe, such as almond or coconut yogurt.
- If you prefer a sweeter taste, you can add a bit more honey or maple syrup to the oats before soaking overnight.
- The chia seeds and shredded coconut add extra fiber and healthy fats, but you can omit them if desired.
- For a tropical twist, you can also add some diced pineapple or banana to the oats.
- This recipe can be easily doubled or tripled to make multiple servings for meal prep.
- You can also use frozen mango if fresh is not available, just make sure to let it thaw before adding it to the oat mixture.ğŸ˜‹ğŸ˜‹ğŸ˜‹

*A jar of homemade orange marmalade, next to a fresh orange half.*

This easy Orange Marmalade recipe is made using fresh oranges and lemon. It only takes a few simple steps and is absolutely delicious! Enjoy it slathered on toast, pork chops, chicken, or stirred into your yogurt or overnight oats.
A jar of homemade orange marmalade, next to a fresh orange half.
Why this is the best marmalade:
Versatile â€“ Serve it on grilled pork tenderloin, grilled chicken, stirred in greek yogurt or overnight oats, or simply slathered on toast!
Delicious â€“ This marmalade tastes so much better than anything you can get in the store. It tastes so fresh and tasty!
Quick â€“ A lot of recipes are more time consuming with a more complicated process. This marmalade is quick to make and only has a few easy steps!

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: Oranges: Preferably choose organic oranges since the skins have not been treated with pesticides and arenâ€™t waxy. Choose thin skinned, oranges for best results, so thereâ€™s less plith to make the marmalade bitter.
Recommended oranges for marmalade: naval, Seville, Cara Cara, blood oranges, mandarin, tangerines, or a combination.
Lemon: citric acid to help the jam set up and make it safe for canning.

Sweetener: helps preserve the marmalade, balance the flavors, and helps it to set up. You could try using Â½ sugar and Â½ Splenda/sweetener, but I donâ€™t recommended reducing the sweetener unless you are okay with a runnier marmalade, and only if you donâ€™t plant to can/preserve it.

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: The four ingredients needed to make orange marmalade.
Oranges contain so much natural pectin that the marmalade will thicken without any added pectin (unlike with my peach, strawberry or raspberry jam, that all require pectin). Pretty cool!

Prepare oranges: Wash oranges and lemon, thoroughly scrubbing the peels. Cut off ends of the oranges then cut each orange in half, and then cut each half into 4, so youâ€™re left with 8 pieces of orange. Discard any seeds.
Four fresh oranges on a plate, quartered and chopped.
Puree: Place oranges in food processor and pulse until rind is in very small pieces. Meanwhile, place a plate in the freezer, for later use.
Pureed oranges in a food processor.
Add to saucepan: Add oranges to a saucepan on the stove over medium heat. Zest lemon and squeeze the juice into the pot. Add water and sweetener and stir well.
Pureed oranges, sugar, lemon and water in a large pot.
Cook: Bring mixture to a boil. Simmer for 30-35 minutes until thickened.
Orange marmalade cooking and thickening in a saucepan.
Test if itâ€™s ready: Use the frozen plate to test for doneness. When itâ€™s done, it will be a soft gel that moves slightly. If it is still thin and runs easily on the plate, keep cooking.
A spoonful of orange marmalade placed on a cold plate, to test of it's ready.
Pour into jars or containers with a lid. Cool to room temperature then refrigerate for up to 2 weeks or freeze for up to 3 months.
Orange marmalade poured into jam jars.

Canning Instructions: Cook mixture to about 220 degrees F on an instant read thermometer, then pour into sterilized jars, and top with new lids and rings that have been washed in warm soapy water. Process in water bath canner for 10 minutes. Allow to sit at room temperature for 24 hours, then store in a cool dry place for 6-10 months. Once opened, refrigerate marmalade for up to 2 weeks.
What if my marmalade didnâ€™t thicken? Stir in a package of liquid fruit pectin and boil for 1 minute.
Why is my marmalade too thick? It was cooked too long. Return to pot over medium heat and stir in additional water.

How to avoid bitter aftertaste:? The white plith that lines the orange can cause the marmalade to be bitter but is important in adding a natural pectin. This is why I suggest buying oranges with a thin skin. If your oranges have an overly thick layer of plith, scrape some out before adding to food processor.
To Store: This easy marmalade recipe can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.
To Freeze: Freeze in a freezer safe container for up to 3 months.
Other Fruits: Combine with other citrus fruits, like grapefruit or pomelo (just make sure the end weight of the fruit is the same)
Ginger: Add a pinch of freshly chopped ginger root.
Add Cinnamon Stick and a whole clove to the mixture while cooking, then remove.
Pure Vanilla Extract: add a splash at the end.
A jar of homemade orange marmalade, next to a fresh orange half.

An easy cultured vegan yogurt recipe that's smooth, tangy, exceptionally thick & creamy & just perfect for dolloping on anything and everything! Easy to make with or without an Instant Pot.
a large bowl of yogurt with chocolate granola and raspberries
We're jumping back on the fermentation train for this vegan yogurt recipe. And it's a whole lot quicker and easier than making sourdough starter or sourdough bread so you're A-Ok!
And this vegan yogurt is so good! We're talking sheer yogurt decadence. It's smooth, tangy and unlike many other homemade vegan yogurt recipes, it is exceptionally thick and creamy.

Yep, this cultured vegan yogurt recipe is THICK. And it continues to thicken as it sits in the fridge. If you leave it there for a few days it's almost Greek yogurt-like. And you won't be needing any expensive probiotics, powdered starters or thickeners like agar agar, tapioca or xanthan gum either.

Most mainstream yogurt you buy at the grocery store is made with dairy, usually cow's milk, but also sometimes sheep or goat milk. This means it is not vegan. However, there are a growing number of really good store bought vegan yogurts available. They are made with plant-based milks like coconut milk, oat milk, almond milk, cashew milk and soy milk.
a tray with open jars of vegan yogurt on it

Most vegan yogurt contains the same gut-friendly probiotics that non-vegan yogurts do, and that includes this recipe, which when made the first time is "seeded" with probiotics from a store bought yogurt and then cultured. For future batches you can use a spoonful of your own homemade yogurt to start the culturing process which means you won't need one from the store.

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: Wondering how you can possibly make vegan yogurt without probiotics or special yogurt starters?

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: These are the ingredients you need to make my vegan yogurt recipe and why you need them:

Light canned coconut milk - Light canned coconut milk because it gives consistent results and makes the yogurt really rich, decadent, thick and creamy without an obvious coconut taste. I do not recommend you use any other milk.
Raw cashew nuts - These add a lovely cashew flavour and also work to make this yogurt extra thick and creamy.

A tiny bit of store bought vegan yogurt - This acts as the starter. It contains the live cultures that will ferment your yogurt. You only need this the first time you make it. For subsequent batches you can use a tiny bit of your own homemade vegan yogurt instead.

Maple syrup - Maple syrup is always my first choice because it is the most natural sweetener, but or agave or white/cane sugar will work too. It's necessary for the bacteria to feed on. It won't make your yogurt sweet.
You will also need some glass jars with lids. I use cleaned up empty jam jars. I don't recommend making this recipe in one big pot, or directly in the inner pot of an Instant Pot.
3 small jars of vegan yogurt, one with a spoon in it and one topped with fruit
Do I Need An Instant Pot To Make Vegan Yogurt?

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: An Instant Pot with a designated yogurt button provides the perfect environment for making this vegan yogurt recipe and it's the quickest method too. You don't have to use one though. You can make it without an Instant Pot and instructions are included.
Want know how to make the best vegan yogurt?
It's much easier than you might think and you can make it with an Instant Pot or without one.
*Here's exactly how it's done with step-by-step pictures:*
Step 1 - Soak the cashews in boiling water.

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: Step 2 - Add them and the other ingredients to a blender and blend until completely smooth.
vegan yogurt mixture in a blender
jars of vegan yogurt before culturing
Step 4 - Place in an Instant Pot on the yogurt setting or leave in a warm place to ferment.
jars of vegan yogurt in an Instant Pot
Step 5 - Chill thoroughly before serving. When you remove it from the fridge it will be very thick. The longer you leave it there the thicker it will get.
The fermentation makes it really bubbly. Here's what it will look like when you first spoon some out:
thick vegan yogurt in a jar with a spoon removed showing the bubbly fermented texture
It will be incredibly thick but once you stir it up it becomes super, silky smooth like this:
smooth and creamy vegan yogurt in a jar
Step 6 - IMPORTANT - Before you eat it all remember to save a few tablespoons of yogurt to culture your next batch!
How To Culture Yogurt Without An Instant Pot

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: The easiest way to incubate and culture your homemade vegan yogurt is with an Instant Pot that has a yogurt setting. That will keep it at a consistent temperature throughout with no effort from you. And it's no secret that I love my Instant Pot. I use it for something nearly every single day, including recipes like my Instant Pot Black Beans, Instant Pot Portobello Pot Roast and Instant Pot Tomato Soup and also for cooking rice, grains and oatmeal etc.

A yogurt maker would work well too and if you don't have either of those then you will need to keep your yogurt at a temperature of between 29 Â° C (85 Â° F) and 46 Â° C (115 Â° F). Anything below 29 Â° C (85 Â° F) and you'll have trouble getting it to culture.

It is also really important that the yogurt doesn't get close to or above 49Â°C (120 Â°F) because at that temperature the yogurt cultures will start to be killed off and the recipe won't work. Because of this I highly suggest you check the temperature of the yogurts location with a thermometer before you start incubating it if you aren't using the controlled environment of an Instant Pot or yogurt maker.
*Here are some suggestions for ways to keep your yogurt warm so it cultures successfully:*
Warm house? - If your house is around 29 Â°C (85 Â°F) or more you can leave the covered jars on your countertop away from direct sunlight and in a spot where they won't be disturbed.

In your oven - Preheat your oven to 200 Â° C (400 Â°F) for 1 minute then turn it off. Sit your jars on a baking tray and place them in the oven on the top shelf with the oven light on. Do not open the door for at least 10 hours or the heat will escape.
Use your home heating - Place your jars of yogurt near (but not too near) the furnace, radiator, fireplace, stove.
On top of your fridge/fridge freezer - This is usually a nice warm spot and works well if you don't have built in appliances.
A warm closet - I have forced air heating in my house and the closets have vents into them and get really warm.
a jar of creamy vegan yogurt with a spoon in it
Follow the recipe exactly. Vegan yogurt is finicky. If you make any changes at all it might not work as well or even at all.
Be sure to soak the cashews even if you have a high powered blender. We want this super-duper smooth.
Do not omit the sweetener. It is necessary for the bacteria to feed on. Don't worry, your yogurt won't taste sweet because it's all consumed by the time the yogurt has fermented.

Canned light coconut milk should be used to make this vegan yogurt recipe. I don't recommend using full fat coconut milk as it will make the yogurt too firm and it also tends to cause separation to occur. Don't be tempted to buy full fat canned coconut milk and dilute it yourself to make "light" coconut milk. That will not work in this recipe.

Ensure the yogurt you use to "seed" your yogurt is a cultured/live one. Most are but double check. If you don't like the results using a particular brand of yogurt try another one next time. Better quality yogurts will give better results.
Makes sure everything is very, very clean.

For this recipe I recommend incubating the yogurt in glass jars. I do not recommend you make it in one big pot, like the Instant Pot's inner pot. This is because this yogurt gets the very best texture when it is completely undisturbed while it incubates and chills. If you stir it or disturb it you will lose the lovely thick, creamy texture.
If using an Instant Pot do not set your jars on the trivet. They need to be directly in contact with the inner pot. Don't use the trivet at all.
Don't use metal utensils, pots or bowls as there's a small chance prolonged contact with them could harm the bacteria in the yogurt.
Try not to disturb the yogurt in the jars. It gets much thicker if you leave it well alone.
If you've got an Instant Pot with a yogurt function use it. It makes this process so easy!
I like to make my yogurt just before I go to bed. That way the incubation time happens while you sleep.

I don't recommend adding anything prior to culturing your vegan yogurt because it might hinder the process, but after it has cultured and chilled and you are happy with tanginess feel free to stir though:

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: Keep your vegan yogurt in lidded jars in the refrigerator. It will keep for 7 to 10 days depending on your fridge temperature. It will continue to thicken and get more tangy. I do not recommend freezing this yogurt.
Uses for vegan yogurt are wide and varied. I suggest keeping a jar in the fridge at all times so you can eat it on repeat for breakfast, snack and dessert.
a healthy chocolate banana breakfast bar with a dollop of yogurt on top
It's very hard to make thick vegan yogurt without adding a thickener of some kind. Store bought vegan yogurts all contain them. The most common thickeners are agar agar, tapioca flour or xanthan gum.

In this recipe though we are blending soaked cashew nuts into the light coconut milk to naturally thicken it. The combination of the creamy canned coconut milk, the cashews and the fermentation make a really thick and creamy vegan yogurt.
a bowl of vegan yogurt topped with granola and fresh raspberries
An easy cultured vegan yogurt recipe that's smooth, tangy, exceptionally thick & creamy & just perfect for dolloping on anything and everything!
PREP TIME: 10minutes minutesFERMENTATION TIME 10hours hoursTOTAL TIME 10hours hours 10minutes minutesSERVINGS 6 servings of about Â½ cup (60ml)

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: â–¢1 cup (140 grams) raw cashew nuts
â–¢1 standard can (400ml / 13.5 oz) light canned coconut milk (no other milk will work) * see notes

â–¢2 tablespoons vegan yogurt , be sure it is one with live probiotic cultures. Almost all are but double check. Note that you only need store bought yogurt the first time you make it then you use your own homemade yogurt for subsequent batches
â–¢2 tablespoons maple syrup , or agave or the same amount of white or cane sugar (do not omit - and don't worry, the yogurt will not taste sweet)

Make sure everything you will be using is scrupulously clean. I run my glass jars, and lids through the dishwasher on the hottest setting. You can also wash them in hot soapy water and put them on a baking tray in an oven at 135 Â°C (275Â°F) for 15 to 20 minutes or clean the jars in hot soapy water, rinse them, then put them still drippy and wet into the microwave. Microwave them on high for 45 seconds (do not put metal lids in the microwave - Soak them in boiling water). I also wash my blender jar in hot soapy water, then rinse and fill with boiling water from the kettle, let it sit for a few minutes then pour it out.
Put the cashews in a small bowl and cover them completely with boiling water. Leave them to soak for 20 to 30 minutes. Don't skip this step.
Run a kettle of boiling water through your sieve then drain the cashews really well and add them to a blender. Add the coconut milk, yogurt and maple syrup, then blend until it is completely smooth.

Decant the mixture into clean and dry jars. Any combination of jar sizes that will hold a total of about 600ml (just under 3 cups). I like to use small ones so I have individual sized servings. If you plan on using an Instant Pot make sure before you start filling the jars that they will fit easily together inside the metal inner bowl.

If using an Instant Pot - Place the uncovered yogurt filled jars into the metal inner pot of the Instant Pot. Do not use the trivet and do not add any water to the pot. The jars should be in direct contact with the bottom of the pot and have no lids or other covering on them. Place the lid of the Instant Pot on and close it, then close the steam vent. Press the yogurt button (check that the display says "normal" and not "boil", then adjust the time depending on how long you would like your yogurt to ferment. I suggest a minimum of 10 hours. That will give you a nice thickness and a slight tang. 11.5 hours will give you a more pronounced tang and is how long I leave mine. Do not disturb the Instant Pot/yogurt during this time. You can check it after 10 or 11 hours though. Use a spoon to take a little bit from one jar (without stirring it up first)and taste it. Put the Instant Pot back on again for another hour or two if it's not quite tangy enough.

If you don't have an Instant Pot - Cover the filled jars with cheesecloth, clean fluff-free dish towels/cloths, any clean breathable fabric, or paper towels and elastic bands or string to hold it in place. To culture successfully you need to keep the yogurt at a consistent temperature of anywhere between 29 Â° C (85 Â° F) and 46 Â° C (115 Â° F).
If your house is 29 Â°C (85 Â°F) or more you can leave the covered jars on your countertop away from direct sunlight.

If your house is cooler than that, turn your oven to 200 Â° C (400 Â°F) for just 1 minute and no longer. Then turn it off and turn the oven light on. Place the covered jars on a baking tray (for stability) in the oven on the top shelf, with just the oven light on. Do not open the door while it is culturing or you will let the heat out. Also make sure that no-one turns the oven on. A note stuck to the door is a good idea.

Do not disturb the yogurt while it is culturing. At 38 Â° C (100 Â°F) the yogurt will take between 10 to 12 hours to culture, thicken nicely and get a good tang. If the temperature is cooler than that it will take longer and if it's warmer then it will happen more quickly. I suggest testing it by scooping a tiny bit out and tasting it after about 10 hours have passed, then add on more time if you want it to be tangier.

Remember that at anything much below a temperature of 29 Â° C (85 Â° F), culturing the yogurt could be problematic, and anything much over 49Â°C (120 Â°F) and the good bacteria will be killed. The yogurt will not culture if that happens. To be absolutely sure that conditions will be right I suggest having a practice run before. Check the temperature of your oven with a thermometer after your oven has preheated for the 1 minute and the light has been turned on. If you find it isn't in the right temperature range there are more suggestions in the recipe notes for ways to incubate.

Once the yogurt has incubated and has reached the right amount of tanginess for you, cover securely with a lid and refrigerate thoroughly. Do not stir it. For best results it needs to be undisturbed until completely chilled. It will thicken more as it chills and will continue to thicken the longer you leave it before eating.
Remember to save a few tablespoons of your yogurt so that you can use it to culture your next batch of homemade vegan yogurt.
If you prefer a sweet yogurt, add more sweetener after the yogurt has fermented and chilled.

*The milk you use must be light canned coconut milk.  Light coconut milk gives the best and most consistent results. You absolutely cannot use homemade coconut milk, coconut milk from a carton, diluted full fat canned coconut milk, or any other type of plant milk for this recipe. They will not work.  I do not recommend using full fat canned coconut milk because it tends to cause separation issues and makes the yogurt way too thick (almost solid) when chilled.
For slightly thinner yogurt you can safely increase the amount of light coconut milk to 480 ml / 2 cups.

*Use glass jars* - For this recipe I recommend incubating the yogurt in glass jars. I do not recommend you make it in one big pot, like the Instant Pot's inner pot. This is because this yogurt gets the very best texture when it is completely undisturbed while it incubates and chills. If you stir it or disturb it you will lose the lovely thick, creamy texture.

*Temperature* - If you don't use an Instant Pot or yogurt maker which will control the temperature and keep it consistent, I would highly suggest you check the temperature of the yogurts location with a thermometer. It is really important that the yogurt stays consistently between 29 Â° C (85 Â° F) and 46 Â° C (115 Â° F).

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: 2. In a small bowl, mix together the grated ginger, soy sauce, rice vinegar, honey, cornstarch, and water. Set aside.
3. In a large skillet or wok, heat the vegetable oil over medium-high heat.
4. Add the sliced onion and minced garlic to the skillet and stir-fry for 2-3 minutes, until the onion is translucent.
5. Add the tempeh cubes to the skillet and stir-fry for 5-7 minutes, until the tempeh is golden brown and crispy.

6. Push the tempeh to one side of the skillet and add the sliced bell pepper, carrot, broccoli, snow peas, and mushrooms to the other side. Stir-fry for 3-4 minutes, until the vegetables are slightly softened.

7. Mix the tempeh and vegetables together in the skillet and add the ginger-soy sauce mixture. Stir everything together and let it cook for an additional 2-3 minutes, until the sauce has thickened and coated everything.
8. Season with salt and pepper, to taste.

*What Is Tempeh (and How to Cook It)*
What is tempeh and how do you cook it? Here Iâ€™m sharing a guide to all things tempeh along with my favorite marinated tempeh recipe.
If youâ€™re new to tempeh, youâ€™re in the right place because I have created a guide to teach you all about tempeh, itâ€™s health benefits and how to cook it!

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: You may have seen some of my tempeh recipes and wondered what tempeh is. For starters, itâ€™s a plant-based protein made of cooked soybeans (think edamame) that have been fermented. The fermentation process binds the soybeans into a cake/patty, which is what youâ€™ll find at your local grocery store. Some varieties of tempeh only include soybeans, but others will contain grains like barley, rice, flax or millet along with the soybeans.

Tempeh on its own has a mild, nutty flavor thatâ€™s often described as earthy. Like most proteins, it really takes on the flavor of the dish! When prepared with marinades or sauces, it absorbs those flavors and the end result is so tasty.
Tempeh is related to tofu, but they arenâ€™t the same thing! They are both made from soy, but other than that theyâ€™re actually quite different.

Tempeh is less processed, fermented and has a stronger flavor and a bit more texture. Tofu is more processed and has a milder flavor with basically no texture! Tofu can be blended up into a creamy sauce or soup or can be fried for more texture, but in general it is much smoother than tempeh.

I also find tempeh a bit easier to work with because thereâ€™s minimal prep work. With tofu you have to account for extra time to press it and with tempeh you simply open the package and youâ€™re ready to chop and cook!
Side by side tempeh rectangles. On the left, the tempeh is out of the packaging, on the right is Lightlife tempeh in the packaging.

Iâ€™ve tried a ton of different tempeh varieties and Lightlife is definitely my favorite for a few reasons: itâ€™s organic, GMO-free and easy to find in mainstream stores. I gravitate towards the Three Grain variety because it is the mildest in terms of taste, but I like the original as well!
You can buy tempeh in most major grocery stores and at every health food store. Youâ€™ll find it in the refrigerated section, usually by the produce or other plant-based proteins.
A square of tempeh that has been sliced into long, thin sections.
Tempeh is incredibly healthy! Not only is it a complete protein, but itâ€™s a good source of iron, prebiotics, B vitamins and manganese. A 1 cup serving of tempeh has a whopping 31 grams of protein!!

As I mentioned above, tempeh is a fermented food. This fermentation process breaks down phytic acid, which can inhibit mineral absorption. This means the minerals in tempeh are easier to digest and tempeh is also less likely to cause gas or indigestion when compared to other beans. I donâ€™t know about you, but less gas and bloating is always a win in my book!
Three versions of tempeh that have been sliced, cubed, and cut into triangles.

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: There are so many different ways to cut tempeh, but here are my go-to methods:

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: Thin slices: if Iâ€™m using tempeh to make my tempeh bacon, blackened tempeh salad or vegan breakfast sandwich I like to cut the tempeh into 1/4â€ thick strips/slices.

Cubes or triangles: if the tempeh is the star of the recipe like in this vegan sweet and sour or tempeh butternut squash bake I like to cut it into cubes or triangles. For cubes, just try to keep cut them into the same sized cubes so they cook evenly. To cut tempeh into triangles, cut the tempeh in half width-wise. Cut each half in a star pattern to get 16 mini triangles per package of tempeh, 32 triangles total.

Crumbled: crumbled tempeh is a great substitute for recipes that typically have ground meat like these tempeh tacos or this tempeh bolognese sauce. To crumble tempeh, simply break it apart with your hands until you reach a desired consistency, similar to that of ground meat.
A close up of tempeh triangles marinating in a maple balsamic glaze.

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: Packaged tempeh is pre-cooked so you can easily enjoy it right from the package (on sandwiches, salads, etc), but I highly recommend cooking it so that it tastes better.

A lot of people suggest steaming the tempeh before marinating or cooking to help remove any bitterness. I honestly donâ€™t take the time to do this, but if youâ€™d like to try it hereâ€™s the process. To steam the tempeh, cut it as desired, place in a steamer basket, cover and steam for 10-15 minutes. If you donâ€™t have a steamer basket, you can fill a saucepan with 1-2 inches of water and bring it to a boil. Once boiling place the tempeh in the saucepan, cover and reduce heat to a simmer and cook for 10-15 minutes.

My favorite way to make tempeh taste amazing is to marinate it! You can marinate in the fridge anywhere from one hour to overnight. The longer it marinates the longer the tempeh has time to soak up all the flavors. Iâ€™m sharing a simple tempeh marinade below made of maple syrup, balsamic vinegar, oil, tamari and garlic. Itâ€™s a staple recipe in our house!
Once your tempeh is prepped and marinated, itâ€™s time to cook it! You have a few options. Hereâ€™s what I recommend:
Pan sautÃ© â€“ I typically sautÃ© my tempeh. Heat 1 Tablespoon of oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add the tempeh and cook until golden brown, about 4-5 minutes per side.

Bake â€“ Baking tempeh is a great hands-off cooking option! Line a baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone mat. Spread the tempeh evenly and bake at 400ÂºF for about 25 minutes or until golden brown.

Air fry â€“ If you have an air fryer, this is a great option for crispy and delicious tempeh! Add the tempeh to the basket and bake at 375ÂºF for about 15 minutes. Toss every 5 minutes for even cooking.
Marinated tempeh that's finished cooking in a large skillet.
How to Serve This Marinated Tempeh

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: This marinated tempeh is lovely served over rice or another grain like quinoa or millet. You can also serve it on cauliflower rice for a low-carb option. You can also pair it with a veggie side like my roasted broccoli or kale salad or try it in my tempeh bowls with pumpkin rice.
This easy marinated tempeh is my favorite way to cook tempeh. The maple balsamic sauce gives the tempeh so much flavor!

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: â–¢2 teaspoons avocado , or olive oil
â–¢3 Tablespoons low sodium tamari, soy sauce or coconut aminos
â–¢1 Tablespoon avocado or olive oil, for cooking
Remove tempeh from package and chop into small triangles by cutting the tempeh in half width-wise. Cut each half in a star pattern to get 16 mini triangles per package of tempeh, 32 triangles total.

In a small bowl combine maple syrup, balsamic vinegar, tamari, 2 teaspoons oil and minced garlic. Add tempeh triangles into a shallow dish with a large surface area, pour maple balsamic marinade over the tempeh, toss to coat and let tempeh marinate in the fridge for 1 â€“ 24 hours. Stir the mixture a couple times while marinating, if possible.

Pan-glaze the tempeh by heating 1 Tablespoon avocado oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Once oil is hot, add the tempeh (without pouring the marinade in) and cook until golden brown on each side, allowing 4-5 minutes per side. Pour the maple balsamic marinade into the pan with the tempeh and simmer another 5-7 minutes, or until the sauce has reduced creating a glaze on the tempeh. Toss the tempeh a couple times during this process.

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: Once the sauce has thickened and all tempeh pieces are coated, the tempeh is ready to be served. I recommend serving it over rice, cauliflower rice or another grain and a veggie side.

ingredients: 1. Peel and cube the potatoes, and set aside.
2. Heat the vegetable oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Add the cumin and mustard seeds, and sautÃ© for 1 minute.
3. Add the onion and sautÃ© for 2-3 minutes, or until lightly browned.
4. Add the potatoes and sautÃ© for 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.

8. Fold the chapati in half and serve warm.

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen

ingredients: 1. Heat the oil in a large pan over a medium-high heat. Add the chopped onion and fry until golden.
2. Add the cubed potatoes and fry for a few minutes.
3. Add the turmeric, garam masala, chilli powder, cumin powder, and salt, to taste. Fry for a few more minutes.
4. Reduce the heat to low and cover the pan. Simmer for about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
5. Once the potatoes are cooked, remove the pan from the heat.
6. Unwrap the chapatis and place one on a flat surface. Spoon half of the potato curry mixture onto the center of the chapati.
7. Fold the chapati in half so that the edges meet. Press the edges together to seal.
8. Heat a non-stick pan over a medium heat. Place the chapati turnover onto the pan and cook for 2-3 minutes, until golden brown.
9. Flip the chapati and cook on the other side for 2-3 minutes.
10. Remove from the heat and transfer onto a plate.
11. Repeat the process with the remaining chapati, potato curry mixture, and oil.
12. Cut the turnovers in half and garnish with the chopped coriander leaves. Serve hot.

ingredients: Prepare flax egg in a bowl by mixing flax seed meal with water.
SautÃ© minced garlic with a tbsp of olive oil in a skillet until slightly browned. Cool slightly and add to the bowl with flax egg.
Add 25g breadcrumbs, chopped basil, chopped sun-dried tomatoes, salt, pepper and a tbsp of olive oil. Blend them together.
Add chickpeas, and blend everything together. Grind them well, but do not make it pasty.
Form into balls - about 12 in total. Then roll in additional bread crumbs.
Brown them for about 5 minutes in the skillet with some olive oil, shaking the pan to roll them around to brown all sides.
Put meatballs on a bare baking sheet and transfer to the preheated oven (375F/190C) and bake for 15 minutes.
In the meantime prepare some vegan spaghetti and tomato sauce.
Once meatballs are golden brown, remove from oven. Let cool briefly before serving.

*Lemon Blueberry Scones - A Bright and Tangy Family Day Treat*

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: - 100g cold butter, cut into small pieces

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: 1. Preheat your oven to 375ÂºF (190ÂºC) and line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
2. In a large bowl, mix together the flour, sweetener, baking powder, and salt.

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: 3. Cut the cold butter into small pieces and add it to the dry ingredients. Using your hands or a pastry cutter, work the butter into the flour mixture until it resembles coarse crumbs.
4. In a separate bowl, beat the egg and milk together. Add in the lemon zest and mix well.
5. Pour the wet mixture into the dry mixture and stir until a dough forms. Gently fold in the blueberries.
6. On a lightly floured surface, knead the dough a few times and then shape it into a disc about 1 inch thick.
7. Using a sharp knife, cut the disc into 8 equal wedges.
8. Place the scones on the prepared baking sheet and brush the tops with lemon juice.
9. Bake for 18-20 minutes or until the scones are golden brown.
10. Allow the scones to cool for a few minutes before dusting with powdered sweetener.
11. Serve warm as a delightful breakfast treat for your family .

_These Lemon Blueberry Scones are the perfect way to start off Mother's Day with a bright and tangy flavor. The zesty lemon and juicy blueberries combine to create a burst of flavor in every bite. These scones are also a great make-ahead breakfast option, allowing you to spend more time with your family on a special day._

*Make sure to use cold butter when making the dough, as it helps create a flaky and tender texture. The lemon zest adds a refreshing tanginess to the scones, while the lemon juice adds a touch of brightness. The blueberries add a pop of color and a burst of sweetness.*

ingredients: 1. In a large pot, heat vegetable oil over medium heat. Add chopped onion, minced garlic, grated ginger, and chopped chili. Cook for 2-3 minutes until the onions are soft and translucent.
2. Add the cubed pumpkin and potatoes to the pot. Stir to combine with the onion mixture.
3. In a small bowl, mix together the curry powder, ground cumin, ground coriander, and turmeric. Sprinkle the spice mixture over the vegetables in the pot. Stir to coat the vegetables evenly.
4. Pour in the coconut milk and vegetable broth. Stir well and bring the curry to a simmer.

5. Allow the curry to cook for 20-25 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the pumpkin and potatoes are soft and cooked through. If the curry becomes too thick, add a splash of water or more vegetable broth.
6. Taste the curry and add salt, if needed, to adjust the seasoning.

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: 7. Serve the pumpkin and potato curry over a bed of cooked basmati rice. Garnish with chopped fresh cilantro, if desired.

*Enjoy this flavorful and hearty as a delicious and satisfying meal. The creamy coconut milk and warm spices make this curry the perfect comfort food for a chilly evening. This recipe is also great for meal prepping and can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.*

ingredients: *_Spicy Beetroot and Carrot Salad with Cumin and Coriander_*

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: 1. In a small pan, toast the cumin and coriander seeds over medium heat until fragrant, about 2-3 minutes. Remove from heat and crush the seeds using a mortar and pestle or a spice grinder.
2. In a mixing bowl, combine the crushed seeds with minced garlic, olive oil, honey, and apple cider vinegar. Whisk until well combined.
3. Add the beetroot and carrot strips to the dressing and toss to coat evenly. Let it marinate for at least 30 minutes, or up to 2 hours, in the refrigerator.

ingredients: One cup dried will yield about 4 cups cooked.
Vegetable broth: 4-5 cups is usually enough to submerge the lentils as they cook thoroughly.
Carrot, celery stalk, and medium onion.
These aromatic vegetables add a wonderful depth of flavor to the soup.
They also provide a hint of sweetness and freshness that balances out the earthiness of the lentils.
Tomato:  adding color to the lentil soup; use fresh chopped tomato, but tomato sauce or tomato paste can also work.

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: Bay leaves: A common ingredient in Italian soups and stews. It adds a subtle herbal note and enhances the overall flavor of the soup.
Sea salt to taste: Season generously towards the end.
Extra virgin olive oil: For sautÃ©ing the soffritto and for the serving.
Drizzle some high-quality olive oil over the finished soup before serving.
Rinse the lentils thoroughly. This helps remove any impurities and ensures a clean taste.
In a large pot, heat olive oil over medium heat.
Add the diced onion, carrot, and celery, and sautÃ© until they soften.
Add the rinsed lentils, bay leaf, chopped tomato, and broth to the pot.
Bring to a boil, then let it simmer in a lower heat for about 30-40 minutes, or until the lentils are tender.
Once the lentils are cooked, remove the bay leaf and season the soup with salt.
Ladle the hot soup into bowls and finish with a drizzle of olive oil and fresh basil or parsley.
Serve as a main course with crusty bread or your favorite side dish.ğŸ˜‹ğŸ˜‹ğŸ˜‹
TOP TIPS FOR A DELICIOUS SOUP
Rinse dried lentils well before cooking to remove any dust or debris.
Lentil soup thickens as it sits â€“ add more broth as needed when reheating.
Use vegetable stock to make a vegetarian lentil soup.
Veggie power: Add more vegetables to the mix.
Zucchini, swiss chard, bell peppers, baby spinach, or fresh kale can be excellent additions to boost the nutritional value.
Creamy soup: If you prefer a creamier texture, blend a portion of the cooked soup using an immersion or regular blender.
Pour it back into the pot and stir to combine.
Add Pasta: Itâ€™s something nice to do with leftovers the next day.
Cook the pasta directly in the lentils, adding about 2 cups of water. Serve with a sprinkle of parmesan cheese.
*If you have leftovers or want to make a big batch of Italian lentil soup ahead of time, hereâ€™s how you can store it:*
Fridge: Allow the soup to cool completely before transferring it to an airtight container.
It will stay fresh in the refrigerator for 4-5 days.
Freeze: If you want to extend the soupâ€™s shelf life, freezing is the way to go.
Portion the soup into freezer-safe containers or resealable freezer bags, leaving some room for expansion. It can be frozen for three months.
Thaw in the refrigerator overnight before reheating.
*DO YOU SOAK THE LENTILS BEFORE COOKING?*
No, you donâ€™t need to soak the lentils before cooking.
*_Unlike some other legumes, lentils cook relatively quickly without pre-soaking. Just give them a good rinse before putting them in the pot._*
CAN I USE CANNED LENTILS INSTEAD OF DRY?
While dried lentils are preferred for their texture and flavor, you can certainly use canned lentils if youâ€™re short on time or like the convenience.
Drain and rinse the canned lentils before adding them to the soup. Remember that canned lentils are already cooked, so youâ€™re the cooking time to avoid overcooking them.
CAN I USE OTHER TYPES OF LENTILS?
Yes! While the recipe calls for dried lentils, you can experiment with different types, such as green lentils, brown, or black.

ingredients: 1. Preheat your oven to 375ÂºF (190ÂºC) and line a baking sheet with parchment paper.

3. Roll out the prata dough on a lightly floured surface until it is about 1/4 inch thick.
4. Using a knife or pizza cutter, cut the dough into small triangle or square shapes, similar to tortilla chips.
5. Place the prata chips on the prepared baking sheet and lightly brush them with olive oil.
6. Sprinkle the garlic and herb mixture evenly over the chips, making sure to coat both sides.
7. Bake in the preheated oven for 10-12 minutes, or until the chips are golden brown and crispy.
8. Remove from the oven and let the chips cool for a few minutes before serving.

*_Prata is a flatbread that can refer to a traditional Slovenian dish or a popular Southeast Asian food:_*

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: _Roti prata: A soft and crispy flatbread that originated in India and is popular in Southeast Asia. It's also known as roti canai or roti cane. The word "roti" means "bread" and "paratha" means "flat". It's often eaten with curry or sugar, and can be made in sweet or savory varieties with ingredients like eggs, cheese._

*Prata (Slovenian dish): A traditional meat dish of Slovenian cuisine. The Pratas Islands are also an archipelago in the South China Sea. The islands are made up of Tungsha Island and two coral reefs, North Vereker Bank and South Vereker Bank. The islands are located between the Pacific and Indian oceans, and are strategically important.*

*_A paratha is a layered, flaky flatbread typically made with ghee or oil and often stuffed with fillings, while a chapati is a simple, thin flatbread made with just flour and water, with a much less layered texture; essentially, a paratha is a richer, more complex version of a chapati due to its layering process with added fat._*
_Parathas are made by repeatedly folding the dough with ghee or oil, creating layers that result in a flaky texture, whereas chapatis are simply rolled out without any layering._
*Parathas incorporate a significant amount of ghee or oil during the layering process, making them richer and higher in calories compared to chapatis.*

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen

*_Okra and Tomato Pasta with Caramelized Onion and Garlic Sauce_*

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: 1. Begin by cooking the pasta according to package instructions in a large pot of salted boiling water. Once cooked, drain and set aside.
2. While the pasta is cooking, prepare the okra by washing and trimming off the stems. Cut them into bite-sized pieces.
3. In a large skillet, heat 1 tablespoon of olive oil over medium heat. Add the okra and cook for 5-7 minutes until slightly tender. Set aside.
4. In the same skillet, add another tablespoon of olive oil and the sliced onions. Cook for 10 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the onions are caramelized and golden brown.
5. Add the minced garlic to the skillet with the onions and cook for an additional 2 minutes.
6. Next, add the cherry tomatoes to the skillet and cook for 5 minutes until they start to burst and release their juices.
7. Season the onion and tomato mixture with salt and pepper to taste.
8. Add the cooked pasta and okra to the skillet and toss everything together until well combined.
9. Let the pasta cook for an additional 2-3 minutes to allow the flavors to meld together.
10. Serve the hot, garnished with some fresh herbs or grated parmesan cheese if desired.

ingredients: 1. Begin by heating olive oil in a large pot over medium heat. Add diced onion and cook until softened, about 5 minutes.

3. Add in the seasoning and stir until the okra is evenly coated.
4. Cut the tomatoes into small chunks and add them to the pot. Cook for an additional 5 minutes.
5. Cut the onion  into bite-sized pieces and add them to the pot. Cook.

*_Spicy Okra and Tomato Curry with Caramelized Onions_*

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: - tip of a teaspoon of cayenne pepper

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: 1. Begin by washing and drying 500 grams of okra. Remove the tops and tips of the okra and cut them into 1-inch pieces.

2. Heat 2 tablespoons of vegetable oil in a large pan over medium heat. Add the okra and cook for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until they start to brown. Remove the okra from the pan and set aside.
3. In the same pan, add 2 large sliced onions and cook on low heat for 10-15 minutes, stirring occasionally, until they are caramelized.
4. While the onions are caramelizing, chop 400 grams of tomatoes into small pieces. Crush 2 cloves of garlic and grate 1 tablespoon of ginger.
5. Once the onions are caramelized, add the garlic and ginger to the pan and cook for 1-2 minutes.
6. Add the chopped tomatoes to the pan and cook for 5-7 minutes until they start to break down.
7. Add 1 teaspoon each of cumin, coriander, turmeric, and cayenne pepper to the pan and mix well.
8. Return the okra to the pan and stir everything together. Add salt to taste.
9. Cover the pan and let the curry simmer for 10-15 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the okra is tender.
10. Once the okra is cooked, remove the lid and let the curry cook for an additional 5 minutes to thicken.
11. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve.
Enjoy the delicious and flavorful combination of spicy okra and sweet caramelized onions!ğŸ˜‹ğŸ˜‹ğŸ˜‹

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen

ingredients: 1. Begin by preparing the okra. Wash and dry the okra pods, then trim off the tops and tails. Cut the okra into 1 inch pieces and set aside.

ingredients: 1. Start by washing and dicing the apple into small pieces.

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: 2. In a mixing bowl, combine the oats, diced apple, cinnamon, milk, and honey. Stir well until all the ingredients are evenly mixed.
3. If desired, add chia seeds to the mixture for extra nutrition and texture.
4. Pour the mixture into a Mason jar or any airtight container.
5. Cover and refrigerate overnight, or for at least 4-6 hours.
6. In the morning, take the oatmeal out of the fridge and give it a good stir.
7. If the oatmeal is too thick, you can add a splash of milk to thin it out.
8. Top with chopped nuts for some crunch and extra protein.
_Enjoy your delicious and nutritious for breakfast, or as a quick and easy snack._ğŸ˜‹ğŸ˜‹ğŸ˜‹

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: 1. In a saucepan, combine the groundnuts, rolled oats, water, milk, and salt. Stir well to combine.
2. Bring the mixture to a boil over medium heat, then reduce the heat to low.
3. Let the oatmeal simmer for about 5 minutes, stirring occasionally, until it thickens to your desired consistency.
4. Turn off the heat and let the oatmeal sit for another 2-3 minutes.
5. Stir in the dried fruits and add honey ğŸ¯ ğŸ¯ ğŸ¯ to taste, if desired.
6. Serve the oatmeal hot and enjoy the delicious African flavors!

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: 1. In a medium saucepan, combine the groundnut butter, coconut milk, water, rolled oats, banana slices, honey, chia seeds, ground cinnamon, and vanilla extract. Stir well to combine.
2. Place the saucepan over medium heat and bring the mixture to a boil. Reduce heat to low and let the porridge simmer for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally.
3. While the porridge is simmering, preheat a small non-stick skillet over medium heat. Add the shredded coconut and toast for 2-3 minutes until golden brown. Set aside.
4. Once the porridge is cooked and thickened to your desired consistency, remove from heat and let it cool for a few minutes.
5. Transfer the porridge to a serving bowl and top with the toasted coconut.

_Enjoy your hot, or let it cool down and refrigerate for a yummy breakfast the next day. You can also add additional toppings such as fresh fruit, nuts, or a drizzle of extra honey for added sweetness._

*This creamy and delicious porridge bowl is a perfect blend of African and tropical flavors, making it a unique and flavorful breakfast option. The groundnut butter adds protein and healthy fats, while the coconut milk adds a rich and creamy texture. This recipe can be easily adjusted to your liking by adding more or less water depending on how thick you prefer your porridge. So next time you're craving a warm and comforting breakfast, give this a try!ğŸ˜‹ğŸ˜‹ğŸ˜‹*
*_Mango Coconut Overnight Oats with Vegan Yogurt_*

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: - 1 cup coconut milk (or any plant-based milk)
- Optional toppings: sliced almonds, extra diced mango, and honey (or maple syrup) for sweetness.

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: 1. In a medium-sized bowl, mix together the rolled oats, coconut milk, and vegan yogurt until well combined.

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: 2. Add in the diced mango, chia seeds, and shredded coconut. Stir well to evenly distribute all the ingredients.
3. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap or transfer the mixture into an airtight container.
4. Place the bowl or container in the refrigerator and let the oats soak overnight, or for at least 6-8 hours.
5. In the morning, give the oats a quick stir. If the mixture is too thick, you can add more coconut milk or water to achieve your desired consistency.
6. Transfer the oat mixture into serving bowls or jars. Top with sliced almonds, extra diced mango, and a drizzle of honey (or maple syrup) for sweetness.
Enjoy your delicious and nutritious for a quick and easy breakfast or snack option.
- You can use any type of vegan yogurt for this recipe, such as almond or coconut yogurt.
- If you prefer a sweeter taste, you can add a bit more honey or maple syrup to the oats before soaking overnight.
- The chia seeds and shredded coconut add extra fiber and healthy fats, but you can omit them if desired.
- For a tropical twist, you can also add some diced pineapple or banana to the oats.
- This recipe can be easily doubled or tripled to make multiple servings for meal prep.
- You can also use frozen mango if fresh is not available, just make sure to let it thaw before adding it to the oat mixture.ğŸ˜‹ğŸ˜‹ğŸ˜‹

ingredients: 1. Peel the cassava and cut it into small cubes. Place the cassava cubes in a pot and cover with water. Bring to a boil and let it cook for 15 minutes.

4. In a separate bowl, beat the egg and milk together. Gradually add in the flour, stirring until a smooth batter forms.

5. Heat a non-stick pan over medium heat and add a small amount of oil. Once hot, scoop about 1/4 cup of the cassava mixture onto the pan and flatten it into a pancake shape. Repeat with the remaining mixture, leaving enough space between each pancake.
6. Cook the pancakes for about 3-4 minutes on each side, or until they turn golden brown and crispy.
7. Remove the pancakes from the pan and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to absorb any excess oil.
8. Serve the warm, topped with your favorite condiments such as sour cream or salsa.

Enjoy your delicious and unique twist on traditional pancakes with the added flavor and nutrition of cassava, tomato, and onion. These pancakes are perfect for breakfast, brunch, or even as a savory snack.ğŸ˜‹ğŸ˜‹ğŸ˜‹

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: _In a large bowl, crack and whisk 2 eggs. Tear the tofu into small chunks using your hands and add them to the bowl. If your tofu still has a lot of liquid, squeeze it over the sink to get rid of the excess. Mix well with the eggs._
*Add into the bowl 1.5 teaspoons of curry powder, 1/2 teaspoon of garlic powder, 1/4 teaspoon of salt, and 1/4 cup of panko crumbs. Mix thoroughly to evenly coat the tofu. Set aside.*
*_Heat a large non-stick frying pan with 1-2 tablespoons of cooking oil._*

*Once the oil is hot, add the 1/4 cup of cornflour onto the tofu pieces and mix to coat them evenly. Immediately transfer the tofu chunks into the pan and fry for 8 minutes over medium heat. You may need to use a spatula to separate the chunks as it's a very batter-heavy recipe.*

_Once cooked, if there's some remaining oil in the pan, transfer the chunks into a bowl. Toss them with 1/2 tablespoon of vegetable stock powder. If the pan doesn't have much oil left, mix the vegetable stock powder in the pan to season the tofu evenly._
*These tofu chunks make a great standalone snack or you can even roll them into a wrap for a satisfying lunch.*

ingredients: 1. Begin by preparing the vegetables. Cut the zucchinis into thick slices, deseed and slice the bell peppers, and slice the red onion. Peel and mince the garlic cloves.
2. Preheat your grill to medium-high heat. Meanwhile, drain the block of tofu and pat it dry with paper towels. Cut the tofu into bite-sized cubes.
3. In a small bowl, mix together the soy sauce, honey, ginger powder, and a pinch of salt.
4. In a large bowl, add the sliced vegetables and tofu. Pour the marinade over the vegetables and tofu, and gently toss to ensure everything is coated evenly.

5. Thread the vegetables and tofu onto skewers, alternating between them. If using wooden skewers, make sure to soak them in water for at least 30 minutes beforehand to prevent them from burning on the grill.
6. Grill the skewers for 10-12 minutes, turning occasionally, until the vegetables are slightly charred and the tofu is heated through.
7. While the skewers are grilling, heat a large wok or pan over medium-high heat. Add 2 tablespoons of olive oil and swirl to coat the pan.
8. Cut the sanguage sausages into bite-sized pieces and add them to the pan. Stir-fry for 3-4 minutes until slightly browned.
9. Add the minced garlic to the pan and stir-fry for an additional minute.

recipes.name: Welcome to Healthy By Nature (HBN) vegetarian kitchen
ingredients: 10. Add the cooked rice to the pan and stir-fry for 2-3 minutes until heated through.
11. Once the skewers are done, remove them from the grill and slide the vegetables and tofu off the skewers into the stir-fry pan. Stir-fry for another 2-3 minutes until everything is well.

ingredients: 1. Begin by pressing the tofu. Place the block of tofu on a plate lined with paper towels and cover the top with more paper towels. Place a heavy object, such as a cast iron skillet, on top of the tofu to help press out any excess moisture. Let it sit for 15 minutes while you prepare the vegetables.
2. Wash and chop the bell peppers, zucchini, carrot, and onion into bite-sized pieces. Mince the garlic and grate the ginger.
3. In a small bowl, mix together the soy sauce, sesame oil, cornstarch, chili flakes, and a pinch of salt and pepper. Set aside.
4. Heat a large wok or non-stick pan over medium-high heat and add enough vegetable oil to cover the bottom of the pan.

5. Carefully place the tofu in the hot oil and cook for 2-3 minutes on each side, until crispy and golden brown. Remove the tofu from the pan and place it on a plate lined with paper towels to absorb any excess oil.
6. In the same pan, add the minced garlic and grated ginger. Cook for 1-2 minutes until fragrant.
7. Add the chopped vegetables to the pan and stir-fry for 3-4 minutes, until they begin to soften.
8. Pour the sauce mixture over the vegetables and stir to coat evenly. Cook for an additional 2-3 minutes until the sauce thickens and coats the vegetables.
9. Add the crispy tofu back into the pan and toss to combine with the vegetables and sauce. Cook for another 1-2 minutes until everything is heated through.

*Tofu is made from dried soybeans that are soaked in water, crushed, and boiled. The mixture is separated into solid pulp (okara) and soy â€œmilk.â€ Salt coagulants, such as calcium and magnesium chlorides and sulfates, are added to the soy milk to separate the curds from the whey.*
What is tofu called in English?

_Tofu (è±†è…), sometimes called doufu (usually used in Chinese recipes) or bean curd (literal translation), is a food made from soybeans. In fact, it is a very complex process. Tofu is made by coagulating soy milk into curds._
*Tofu is a vegetable protein. Even though it is derived from a plant (soybeans) it is processed into a protein food.*

*_What Does Tofu Taste Like? Plain tofu has no specific flavor and is honestly, quite bland. This might be why people tend to hate it but the fact that it's bland is exactly why we should LOVE it. The texture of tofu is more important than the taste- all the different types of tofu have different textures._*

_Tofu has fiber, and high-fiber diets keep your colon healthy and cancer risk low. Memory and brain health. Some studies suggest soy foods like tofu might prevent memory loss and trouble thinking as you get older._

*Yes, it's safe to eat raw firm tofu. It has a mild taste and a somewhat spongy texture. To enhance its flavor, you can marinate or season it. Try slicing it into cubes or strips, then marinate in a mixture of soy sauce, sesame oil, and your choice of herbs or spices.*

_Tofu is made from soybeans that are ground in water, heated, and coagulated with minerals like calcium or magnesium salt. The curds are then pressed into a block, which is then sold as tofu. You can buy several different types of tofu, from extra-soft silken tofu to extra-firm tofu._

ingredients: 1. Start by preparing the tofu. Drain the tofu and pat it dry with paper towels. Cut the tofu into small cubes and set aside.
2. In a large pot, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add the chopped onion, minced garlic, and diced peppers. SautÃ© for 5-7 minutes, until the vegetables are softened.
3. Add the tofu cubes to the pot and cook for an additional 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.
4. Drain and rinse the canned beans. Add them to the pot along with the diced tomatoes, chili powder, cumin, oregano, salt. Stir everything together.
5. Pour in the vegetable broth and bring the chili to a boil. Then reduce the heat to low and let it simmer for 15-20 minutes.
6. In a small bowl, mix together the cornstarch with 2 tablespoons of water. Pour this mixture into the chili and stir well. This will help to thicken the chili.
7. Let the chili simmer for an additional 10 minutes. The tofu and beans should now be fully cooked and the chili should have a thick and hearty consistency.
8. Taste the chili and adjust the seasonings to your liking.

ingredients: 1. Heat the vegetable oil in a pan on medium-high heat.
2. Add the onions, ginger, green chili and sautÃ© until lightly browned.
3. Add the cubed paneer and mix.
4. Add the garam masala, cumin powder, turmeric powder, coriander leaves and salt to taste. Mix well.
5. Take the samosas and gently open each one up.
6. Stuff the samosas with the paneer mixture.
7. Heat another pan on medium-high heat and add some vegetable oil.
8. Fry the stuffed samosas until golden brown on both sides.
9. Serve hot with chutney of your choice.

*Paneer can be made with milk, goat milk, sheep milk or cow's milk. Although it is similar to cottage cheese, paneer is usually made without rennet and therefore has a different texture. Paneer is made by curdling milk with a food acid, usually lemon juice or vinegar.*
